assertion: Vegetarian diet would reduce GreenHouse Gas (GHG) emissions.
explanation: Vegetarian diet would reduce GHG emissions per capita from food production by 55%.
nameSource: Tilman & Clark 2014 null Scientific paper

assertion: Vegetarian diet would decrease future agricultural land demand and clearing
explanation: Land clearing leads to GHG emissions and spiecies extinction
nameSource: Tilman & Clark 2014 null Scientific paper

assertion: Vegetarian diet brings health benefits
explanation: Vegetarian diet reduces the relative risk of diabetes, cancer and coronary mortality by 41%, 10% and 20 % respectivly compared to a conventional omnivorous diet.
nameSource: Tilman & Clark 2014 null Scientific paper

assertion: A vegetarian diet can meet current recommendations for key nutrients
explanation: A vegetarian diet can meet current recommandation for protein, n-3 fatty acids, iron, zinc, iodine, calcium, and vitamins D and B12.
nameSource: Craig et al. 2009 null Scientific paper

assertion: A vegan diet may not meet current recommendations for key nutrients
explanation: In some cases, supplements or fortified foods are needed to provide useful amounts of important nutrients (Calcium, Vitamine D and B12).
nameSource: Craig et al. 2009 null Scientific paper

assertion: A vegetarian (vegetarian and vegan) diet is associated with lower risk of death from ischemic heart disease
explanation: Based on blood lipid levels in one large cohort study, the incidence of ischemic heart disease was estimated to be 24% lower in lifelong vegetarians and 57% lower in lifelong vegans compared to meat eaters
nameSource: Craig et al. 2009 null Scientific paper

assertion: A vegetarian (vegetarian and vegan) diet is associated with lower risk of death from ischemic heart disease
explanation: Soluble fiber (Vegetarians consume between 50% and 100% more fiber than nonvegetarians) has been repeatedly shown to lower total and LDL cholesterol levels and to reduce risk of coronary heart disease
nameSource: Craig et al. 2009 null Scientific paper

assertion: Well-planned vegan, lacto-vegetarian, and lacto-ovo-vegetarian diets are appropriate for all stages of the life cycle, including pregnancy and lactation
explanation: Appropriately planned vegan, lacto-vegetarian, and lacto-ovo-vegetarian diets satisfy nutrient needs of infants, children, and adolescents and promote normal growth
nameSource: Craig et al. 2009 null Scientific paper
aim: Providing specific populations with balanced diets

assertion: Vegetarians also appear to have lower low-density lipoprotein cholesterol levels, lower blood pressure, and lower rates of hypertension and type 2 diabetes than nonvegetarians
explanation: Vegetarian diets tend to be lower in saturated fat and cholesterol, and have higher levels of dietary fiber, magnesium and potassium, vitamins C and E, folate, carotenoids, flavonoids, and other phytochemicals. These nutritional differences may explain some of the health advantages of those following a varied, balanced vegetarian diet.
nameSource: Craig et al. 2009 null Scientific paper

assertion: Vegetarians tend to have a lower body mass index and lower overall cancer rates
explanation: Vegetarian diets tend to be lower in saturated fat and cholesterol, and have higher levels of dietary fiber, magnesium and potassium, vitamins C and E, folate, carotenoids, flavonoids, and other phytochemicals. These nutritional differences may explain some of the health advantages of those following a varied, balanced vegetarian diet.
nameSource: Craig et al. 2009 null Scientific paper

assertion: vegans, lacto-ovo vegetarians, pesco-vegetarians, and semi-vegetarians had a lower risk of type 2 diabetes than nonvegetarians.
explanation: Vegetarian diets may carry metabolic advantages for the prevention of type 2 diabetes (Jenkins et al. 2003)
nameSource: Tonstad et al. 2009 null Scientific paper

assertion: vegans, lacto-ovo vegetarians, pesco-vegetarians, and semi-vegetarians had a lower risk of type 2 diabetes than nonvegetarians.
explanation: Intakes of red meat and processed meats were associated with increased risk of diabetes (Fung et al. 2004, Vang et al. 2008)
nameSource: Tonstad et al. 2009 null Scientific paper

assertion: Blood pressure is lower under vegetarian diet.
explanation: The nutrient(s) causing these blood-pressure changes are unknown
nameSource: Rouse et al. 1983 null Scientific paper

assertion: Sufficient calcium intake make an exclusively plant-based diet impractical
explanation: The quantity of vegetables required to reach sufficient calcium intake make an exclusively plant-based diet impractical for most individuals unless fortified foods or supplements are included
nameSource: Weaver et al. 1999 null Scientific paper

assertion: Mothers who were vegetarian in pregnancy had an adjusted odds ratio (OR) of 4.99 (95% confidence interval, CI, 2.10–11.88) of giving birth to a boy with hypospadias, compared with omnivores who did not supplement their diet with iron
explanation: Vegetarians have a greater exposure to phytoestrogens which may have a deleterious effect on the developing male reproductive system.
nameSource: North et al. 2000 null Scientific paper
aim: Providing specific populations with balanced diets

assertion: Ovolacto-vegetarian diet reduces blood pressure
explanation: Vegetarian diet included an increase in the ratio of polyunsaturated to saturated fats and intake of fibre, calcium, and magnesium and a decrease in the intake of protein and vitamin B12
nameSource: Margetts et al. 1986 null Scientific paper

assertion: Vegetarians had a substantially lower risk than non-vegetarians of diabetes as an underlying or contributing cause of death
explanation: The associations observed between diabetes and meat consumption were apparently not due to confounding by over- or under-weight, other selected dietary factors, or physical activity
nameSource: Snowdon & Philips 2011 null Scientific paper

assertion: A low-fat vegan diet improves glycemic control and cardiovascular risk factors in individuals with type 2 diabetes
explanation: A low-fat vegan diet appeared to improve glycemia and plasma lipids in type 2 diabetic patients more than did conventional diabetes diet recommendations
nameSource: Barnard et al. 2006 null Scientific paper
aim: Providing specific populations with balanced diets

assertion: A low-fat vegan diet improves glycemic control and cardiovascular risk factors in individuals with type 2 diabetes
explanation: A low-fat vegan diet appeared to improve glycemia and plasma lipids in type 2 diabetic patients more than did conventional diabetes diet recommendations
nameProperty: Lipid control for type 2 diabetic patients
nameSource: Barnard et al. 2006 null Scientific paper
aim: Providing specific populations with balanced diets

assertion: A vegan diet free of gluten improves the signs and symptoms of rheumatoid arthritis
explanation: The data provide evidence that dietary modification may be of clinical benefit for certain rheumatoid arthritis patients, and that this benefit may be related to a reduction in immunoreactivity to food antigens eliminated by the change in diet
nameProperty: Health status for rheumatoid arthritis patients
nameSource: Halfström et al. 2001 null Scientific paper
aim: Providing specific populations with balanced diets

assertion: "An uncooked vegan diet (""living food"") improves the health of rheumatoid patient"
explanation: The rheumatoid patients subjectively and objectively benefited from the vegan diet rich in antioxidants, lactobacilli and fibre.
nameSource: Hänninen et al. 2000 null Scientific paper
aim: Providing specific populations with balanced diets

assertion: Vegan diet had beneficial effects on fibromyalgia symptoms at least in the short run
explanation: The results revealed significant improvements in Visual analogue scale of pain (VAS), joint stiffness, quality of sleep, Health assessment questionnaire (HAQ), General health questionnaire (GHQ), and a rheumatologist's own questionnaire, caused a significant reduction in body mass index (BMI), total serum cholesterol showed a statistically significant loweringand Urine sodium dropped to 1/3 of the beginning values (p=0.0001) indicating good diet compliance
nameSource: Kaartinen et al. 2009 null Scientific paper
aim: Providing specific populations with balanced diets

assertion: A vegan diet changes the faecal microbial flora in rheumatoid arthritis (RA) patients and they associated with improvement in RA activity.
explanation: A significant, diet-induced change in the faecal flora was observed in the test group (with vegan diet), but not in the control group  (omnivorous).
nameProperty: Health status for rheumatoid arthritis patients
nameSource: Peltonen et al. 1997 null Scientific paper
aim: Providing specific populations with balanced diets

assertion: Maternal vegan diet causing a serious infantile neurological disorder due to vitamin B12 deficiency
explanation: The patient's symptoms included dystrophy, weakness, muscular atrophy, loss of tendon reflexes, psychomotor regression and haematological abnormalities Biochemical investigations revealed (...) low concentrations of serum vitamin B12 in both patient and mother.
nameProperty: Vitamin B12 for infant and mother
nameSource: Kühne et al. 1990 null Scientific paper
aim: Providing specific populations with balanced diets

assertion: Pure vegetarian diet is related with cobalamine (B12 vitamine) deficiency and requires to monitor their urinary MMA (MethylMalonic Acid) levels
explanation: 23 subjects under vegetarian diet (47%) had abnormal urinary MMA (MethylMalonic Acid)) concentrations
nameSource: Donaldson 2000 null Scientific paper

explanation: Cost of production would soar. Eggs and milk would be luxury products. There would be excessive pollution for land necesary to maintain a high number of bovine alive.
nameProperty: Not killing animals in milk and egg production
nameSource: Frédéric Côté-Boudreau - Il n’y a pas d’arguments moraux en faveur du végétarisme null Blog post

assertion: Vegans should reduce their consumption of plants and eat more cows who grazed on pasture, he asserted cows provide lots of protein and calories per head, and would therefore cause the deaths of fewer animals than plant harvesting does
explanation: Steven Davis, A professor of animal science at Oregon State University, published in the Journal of Agricultural and Environmental Ethics based his argument on the theory that modern crop harvesting kills more animals than eating cows who grazed on pasture
nameSource: Our new house - Change the world for animals - The ethical arguments against ethical veganism null Post

assertion: Unfortunately for Davis, his argument that vegan diet result in more animal deaths was based on thin air
explanation: because he didn’t know how many animals die to grow and harvest plants. “[A]ccurate numbers aren’t available comparing the number of animals of the field that are killed with these different cropping systems,” admits the author
nameProperty: Increased animal deaths in vegan diet
nameSource: Our new house - Change the world for animals - The ethical arguments against ethical veganism null Post

assertion: Steven Davis wrongly assumed that equal amounts of land will produce equal amounts of food from crops or from animals on pasture. Once corrected, Steven Davis’s argument made the case for, rather than against, a vegan diet
explanation: In fact, an amount of land will produce much more food when used to grow crops for direct human consumption than when used to raise cattle, provided it is suitable for growing crops
nameSource: Our new house - Change the world for animals - The ethical arguments against ethical veganism null Post

assertion: Ovo-lacto-vegetarianism is not justified by the fact it would be less worse than omnivorism
explanation: Better does not mean good.
nameSource: Frédéric Côté-Boudreau - Il n’y a pas d’arguments moraux en faveur du végétarisme null Blog post

assertion: Davis makes for the numbers of animals being killed by harvesting activity is weak
explanation: Steven Davis' numbers included animals who were killed by predators, and that the argument overlooks ways that humans can be harmed or killed by beef production but not vegetable production.
nameSource: Our new house - Change the world for animals - The ethical arguments against ethical veganism null Post

assertion: Jay Bost, winner of the The New York Times contest inviting readers “to make an argument” that eating meat is ethical, main argument is that one should recognize that all life is just solar energy, choose ethically raised foods and be thankful
explanation: First, you accept the biological reality that death begets life on this planet and that all life (including us!) is really just solar energy temporarily stored in an impermanent form. Second, you combine this realization with that cherished human trait of compassion and choose ethically raised food, vegetable, grain and/or meat. And third, you give thanks.
nameSource: Our new house - Change the world for animals - The ethical arguments against ethical veganism null Post

assertion: The argument of all life coming from the sun is lame and could justify anything
explanation: If all life coming from solar energy justifies to be ethically killed and eaten, why not killing and eating ethically raised humans?  There are reasons for the taboos on cannibalism, such as the recognition of people’s inherent right to life and dignity. Ethical vegans argue that drawing a distinction between human animals, who get to keep this right, and non-human animals, who don’t, is not justifiable.
nameSource: Our new house - Change the world for animals - The ethical arguments against ethical veganism null Post

assertion: Giving thanks to animal is a nice sentiment that does not help the cows slaughtered just a fraction into their life span
explanation: who are we supposed to give thanks to, anyway? Let’s not drag God into this, or the debate will just get uglier. So are we thanking the spirit of the murdered animal? If such a thing exists, I imagine it snorting in indifference at this useless token that serves mostly (if not entirely) to salve the guilt of meat eaters.
nameSource: Our new house - Change the world for animals - The ethical arguments against ethical veganism null Post

assertion: As eating animals is not necessary to be healthy, unecessary harm to animals should be prefered
explanation: Peter Singer (Princeton University and University of Melbourne professor and pioneer of the animal liberation movement) has long argued that, if it is possible to survive and be healthy without eating meat, fish, dairy, or eggs, one ought to choose that option instead of causing unnecessary harm to animals
nameSource: Ethics of eating meat null Wikipedia

assertion: Non human animals are sentient and should be treated through utilitarian ethics
explanation: "In Animal Liberation, Singer argued that, because non-human animals feel, they should be treated according to utilitarian ethics. Peter Singer, in his ethical philosophy of what it is to be a ""person"", argues that livestock animals feel enough to deserve better treatment than they receive"
nameSource: Ethics of eating meat null Wikipedia

assertion: Killing is justifiable in the same specific way as killing a human is.
explanation: Ethical vegetarians say that the reasons for not hurting or killing animals are similar to the reasons for not hurting or killing humans. They argue that killing an animal, like killing a human, can only be justified in extreme circumstances consuming a living creature just for its taste, for convenience, or out of habit is not justifiable
nameSource: Ethics of eating meat null Wikipedia

assertion: Meat mass demand justifies mass production regardless of animal welfare
explanation: Some proponents of meat-eating argue that the current mass demand for meat has to be satisfied with a mass-production system, regardless of the welfare of animals
nameSource: Ethics of eating meat null Wikipedia
aim: Following the law of supply and demand

assertion: Meat mass demand can be met by hunting and free range raising.
explanation: Less radical proponents argue that practices like well-managed free-range rearing and the consumption of hunted animals, particularly from species whose natural predators have been significantly eliminated, could satisfy the demand for mass-produced meat
nameProperty: Meat demand with hunting and free-range rearing
nameSource: Ethics of eating meat null Wikipedia
aim: Following the law of supply and demand

assertion: Ethical means ecological meat
explanation: "Ethical is defined as living in the most ecologically benign way, then in fairly specific circumstances, of which each eater must educate himself, eating meat is ethical."" The specific circumstances he mentions include using animals to cycle nutrients and convert sun to food"
nameSource: Ethics of eating meat null Wikipedia

assertion: Animals may have consciousness and emotions
explanation: "In 2012, a group of well known neuroscientists[19] stated in the ""Cambridge Declaration on Consciousness in Non-Human Animals"" that all mammals and birds (such as farm animals), and other animals, possess the neurological substrates that generate consciousness and are able to experience affective states"
nameSource: Ethics of eating meat null Wikipedia

assertion: Animals do not suffer less than humans
explanation: As noted by John Webster (emeritus professor of animal husbandry at the University of Bristol): People have assumed that intelligence is linked to the ability to suffer and that because animals have smaller brains they suffer less than humans. That is a pathetic piece of logic, sentient animals have the capacity to experience pleasure and are motivated to seek it, you only have to watch how cows and lambs both seek and enjoy pleasure when they lie with their heads raised to the sun on a perfect English summer's day. Just like humans.
nameSource: Ethics of eating meat null Wikipedia

assertion: Meat eaters are in a state of cognitive dissonance regarding the animal they eat
explanation: When people choose to do things about which they are ambivalent and which they would have difficulty justifying, they experience a state of cognitive dissonance, which can lead to rationalization, denial, or even self-deception. For example, a 2011 experiment found that, when the harm that their meat-eating causes animals is explicitly brought to people's attention, they tend to rate those animals as possessing fewer mental capacities compared to when the harm is not brought to their attention. This is especially evident when people expect to eat meat in the near future. Such denial makes it less uncomfortable for people to eat animals. The data suggest that people who consume meat go to great lengths to try to resolve these moral inconsistencies between their beliefs and behaviour by adjusting their beliefs about what animals are capable of feeling
nameSource: Ethics of eating meat null Wikipedia

assertion: the livestock sector emerges as one of the top two or three most significant contributors to the most serious environmental problems
explanation: "at every scale from local to global.""[25] The livestock sector is probably the largest source of water pollution (due to animal wastes, fertilizers, and pesticides), contributing to eutrophication, human health problems, and the emergence of antibiotic resistance. It accounts also for over 8% of global human water use."
nameSource: Ethics of eating meat null Wikipedia

assertion: Livestock is probably the leading player in biodiversity loss,
explanation: it causes deforestation, land degradation, pollution, climate change, overfishing, and invasions by alien species.[25][27][28] A 2017 study by the World Wildlife Fund found that 60% of biodiversity loss can be attributed to the vast scale of feed crop cultivation needed to rear tens of billions of farm animals
nameProperty: Biodiversity loss from feed crop cultivation
nameSource: Ethics of eating meat null Wikipedia

assertion: Livestock is also responsible for at least 20% of the world's greenhouse gas emissions, which are the main cause of the current climate change
explanation: This is due to feed production, enteric fermentation from ruminants, manure storage and processing, and transportation of animal products.[30] The greenhouse gas emissions from livestock production greatly exceeds the greenhouse gas emissions of any other human activity.
nameSource: Ethics of eating meat null Wikipedia

assertion: producing animal-based food is typically much less efficient than the harvesting of grains, vegetables, legumes, seeds, and fruits regarding water and energy consumption
explanation: Producing 1 kg of meat requires up to 15,000 liters of water.[35] According to the United States Department of Agriculture (USDA), growing crops for farm animals requires nearly half of the US water supply and 80% of its agricultural land. Animals raised for food in the US consume 90% of the soy crop, 80% of the corn crop, and 70% of its grain
nameSource: Ethics of eating meat null Wikipedia

assertion: sentience and individual welfare are less important to morality than the greater ecological good.
explanation: "Following environmentalist Aldo Leopold's principle that the sole criterion for morality is preserving the ""integrity, stability and beauty of the biotic community"", this position asserts that sustainable hunting and animal agriculture are environmentally healthy and therefore good"
nameSource: Ethics of eating meat null Wikipedia

assertion: Animal are not moral agents
explanation: it has been argued that a moral community requires all participants to be able to make moral decisions, but animals are incapable of making moral choices (e.g., a tiger would not refrain from eating a human because it was morally wrong it would decide whether to attack based on its survival needs, as dictated by hunger). Thus, some opponents of ethical vegetarianism argue that the analogy between killing animals and killing people is misleading
nameSource: Ethics of eating meat null Wikipedia

assertion: Animal dont make moral choices but humans do and could choose to stop eating animals
explanation: The response of ethical vegetarians is that humans have a choice, whereas animals do not. Hence, if hurting or killing animals is not necessary for human survival or health (as it is necessary for obligate carnivores, such as felids), humans can decide to stop doing it
nameSource: Ethics of eating meat null Wikipedia

assertion: animals raised for food can be treated humanely.
explanation: They're in state-of-the-art confinement facilities. The conditions that we keep these animals in are much more humane than when they were out in the field. Today they're in housing that is environmentally controlled in many respects. And the feed is right there for them all the time, and water, fresh water. They're looked after in some of the best conditions, because the healthier and [more] content that animal, the better it grows. So we're very interested in their well-being up to an extent
nameSource: Ethics of eating meat null Wikipedia

assertion: Humane animal food is impossible
explanation: "Farm Sanctuary argue that commodifying and slaughtering animals is incompatible with the definition of ""humane"""
nameSource: Ethics of eating meat null Wikipedia

assertion: Animals like oysters can be eaten if they dont feel pain
explanation: Biologically, oysters are not in the plant kingdom, but when it comes to ethical eating, they are almost indistinguishable from plants. Oyster farms account for 95 percent of all oyster consumption and have a minimal negative impact on their ecosystems there are even nonprofit projects devoted to cultivating oysters as a way to improve water quality. Since so many oysters are farmed, there's little danger of overfishing. No forests are cleared for oysters, no fertilizer is needed, and no grain goes to waste to feed them—they have a diet of plankton, which is about as close to the bottom of the food chain as you can get. Oyster cultivation also avoids many of the negative side effects of plant agriculture: There are no bees needed to pollinate oysters, no pesticides required to kill off other insects, and for the most part, oyster farms operate without the collateral damage of accidentally killing other animals during harvesting
nameSource: Ethics of eating meat null Wikipedia

assertion: there is no agreement on where to draw the line between organisms that can and cannot feel.
explanation: Montaigne is ecumenical in this respect, claiming consciousness for spiders and ants, and even writing of our duties to trees and plants. Singer and Clarke agree in denying consciousness to sponges. Singer locates the distinction somewhere between the shrimp and the oyster. He, with rather considerable convenience for one who is thundering hard accusations at others, slides by the case of insects and spiders and bacteria, they pace Montaigne, apparently and rather conveniently do not feel pain. The intrepid Midgley, on the other hand, seems willing to speculate about the subjective experience of tapeworms ...Nagel ... appears to draw the line at flounders and wasps, though more recently he speaks of the inner life of cockroaches
nameSource: Ethics of eating meat null Wikipedia

assertion: Agriculture for plants kills more animals than beef from grass-fed ruminants
explanation: Steven Davis, a professor of animal science at Oregon State University, argues that the least harm principle does not require giving up all meat. Davis states that a diet containing beef from grass-fed ruminants such as cattle would kill fewer animals than a vegetarian diet, particularly when one takes into account animals killed by agriculture
nameSource: Ethics of eating meat null Wikipedia

assertion: A vegan diet does not kill more animals than grass-fed beef
explanation: when the numbers are adjusted, Davis' argument shows veganism as perpetrating the least harm
nameSource: Ethics of eating meat null Wikipedia

assertion: Ethical vegans do not consume dairy or eggs because they believe their production causes animal suffering or premature death
explanation: "To produce milk from dairy cattle, most calves are separated from their mothers soon after birth and fed milk replacement in order to retain the cows' milk for human consumption.[58] Animal welfare advocates point out that this breaks the natural bond between the mother and her calf.[58] Unwanted male calves are either slaughtered at birth or sent for veal production.[58] To prolong lactation, dairy cows are almost permanently kept pregnant through artificial insemination.[58] Although cows' natural life expectancy is about twenty years,[57] after about five years the cows' milk production has dropped they are then considered ""spent"" and are sent to slaughter for meat and leather"
nameProperty: Animal suffering in milk and egg production
nameSource: Ethics of eating meat null Wikipedia

assertion: Accidental deaths when cropping plants are not more ethical than the deliberate deaths of the omnivore’s diet
explanation: it was the difference between deliberately shooting someone and putting on a blindfold and shooting in the general direction of a crowd (...) I’m unconvinced that a fawn caught in the blades of a combine would be any less angry because its death was inevitable but unintentional… especially if the responsible parties are running around telling everyone how they don’t kill animals.
nameSource: Medium.com - I Lost an Argument with a Vegan. Here’s what I Learned null Internet article

assertion: Accidental deaths when cropping plants are more ethical than the deliberate deaths of the omnivore’s diet
explanation: it was the difference between deliberately shooting someone and killing them in a traffic accident
nameSource: Medium.com - I Lost an Argument with a Vegan. Here’s what I Learned null Internet article

assertion: It is not possible to prove that agriculture for a vegan diet is sustainable
explanation: The scientific literature only proves the vegan diet is less environmentally harmful than diets that rely on CAFO agriculture
nameSource: Medium.com - I Lost an Argument with a Vegan. Here’s what I Learned null Internet article

assertion: It is not possible to prove that agriculture for a vegan diet is not sustainable
explanation: I was unable to find any scientific studies that even took up the subject the lack of inquiry into this topic is a big part of the reason I focus so heavily on the vegetarian diet instead of omnivorous diet — there are plenty of people justifiably beating the Hell out of the latter.
nameSource: Medium.com - I Lost an Argument with a Vegan. Here’s what I Learned null Internet article

assertion: Animals are necessary to preserve the fertility cycle necessary for plants to grow
explanation: This solution seems much less risky than “green manures and biosolids” which, as stated earlier, will not cover the fertility gap and, having never been applied at global scale, are not proven to produce sustainable yields at scale.
nameSource: Medium.com - I Lost an Argument with a Vegan. Here’s what I Learned null Internet article

assertion: Green manures and biosolids could cover the global fertility gap if animal/synthetic fertilizers were removed
explanation: By using Veganic farming and technology. eg green manure/mulches, supporting phosphate recycling of human waste. I don’t see how animals would help the problems. Indeed animal agriculture often make that worse. If you look at nitrogen cycles for example, it makes little sense to think of manure as adding to nitrogen sustainability. They just move the nitrogen fixed either by bacteria in the roots of some plants, or fixed by humans in the syntheitic production of fertiliser from one area to another. The same thing could be done just by rotational cropping and green manures
nameSource: Medium.com - I Lost an Argument with a Vegan. Here’s what I Learned null Internet article

assertion: As animals can eat other animals we should be, as equals, allowed to eat animals
explanation: there are plenty of animals who are also omnivores, that don’t strictly need to eat meat. As this is a moral conversation, is it unethical for a bear to eat a fish? Or a chimp to have a chipmunk for lunch? If it is fine for them to do so, what distinguishes us? By claiming that we are superior to these animals, and we must function with higher standards, you are implying that these animals are inferior, and as such, don’t necessarily have the same rights, meaning that it doesn’t matter whether we eat these animals or not. If you claim that we are just animals, than you cannot possibly claim to hold humans to a higher standard than our fellow animals.
nameStakeHolder: Internet debate with several Reddit users
nameSource: Reddit - The ethical arguments for veganism are hollow null Reddit Forum

assertion: I think [animal production] is a problem of economics
explanation: Not only this, but any basic understanding of the food pyramid will tell you that we lose roughly 80-90% of all grown calories and nutrition that goes into raising animals for food
nameSource: Reddit - The ethical arguments for veganism are hollow null Reddit Forum

assertion: Meat and dairy products should not be banned but luxury products
explanation: abolishing meat and dairy products is impractical, and in my opinion, unnecessary. But I do believe that for the future good of humankind, these products should be luxury resources, and not commonplace. Something served at high-end restaurants, or specialty stores for dairy
nameStakeHolder: Internet debate with several Reddit users
nameSource: Reddit - The ethical arguments for veganism are hollow null Reddit Forum
aim: Controling the market of food products

assertion: Humans are omnivores
explanation: The fact of the matter is that Humans are omnivores, no, we don’t strictly need to eat meat, but it’s inborn in our genetics to do so. It’s why meat tastes good.
nameStakeHolder: Internet debate with several Reddit users
nameSource: Reddit - The ethical arguments for veganism are hollow null Reddit Forum

assertion: Humans are more herbivorous than omnnivorous
explanation: The classification of animals into these dietary categories is based on behavioural observations, not physiological traits. This means that if an orangutan is observed eating a mouse, it is classified as an omnivore regardless of the fact that it may not be able to digest anything coming from the mouse. Psychologically, humans have more adaptations to a herbivorous diet than an omnivorous one. Also, there is nothing in our genetics that allows us to eat meat. Our genetics allow us to break down proteins, it doesn't care where the proteins come from.
nameStakeHolder: Internet debate with several Reddit users
nameSource: Reddit - The ethical arguments for veganism are hollow null Reddit Forum

assertion: If we are equals to animal humans could kill, rape torture each other
explanation: You don't hold humans to a higher moral standard? Does this only apply to diet? Or would you be okay if I brought a gang of my homies to your house, raped your mother, killed your brothers and sisters and ripped your dad's nuts and watched him bleed out? Why not? Lions do it? Why are you holding me to a higher moral standard than a lion? Appeal to nature, fallacy, you are not a lion/bear/orangutans, etc. debunked. Next.
nameStakeHolder: Internet debate with several Reddit users
nameProperty: Human-animal moral analogy in a civilized world
nameSource: Reddit - The ethical arguments for veganism are hollow null Reddit Forum

assertion: cattle killed do not suffer
explanation: cattle are killed instantly without knowing they what’s about to happen. They don’t feel pain
nameStakeHolder: Internet debate with several Reddit users
nameSource: Reddit - The ethical arguments for veganism are hollow null Reddit Forum

assertion: Cattle killed suffer
explanation: You've quite obviously never spent time in a slaughter house. These animals die in pain, screaming, most of the time. Statements like this are simply not supported by the overwhelming bodies of evidence. You are probably assuming that most animals are slaughtered using a bolt pistol. The bolt pistol does not kill, it stuns. A knife to the neck is what kills. They do feel pain. They do fear death. They do understand what is happening around them when they see a bolt gun go to their companion's head, they do understand that stinking, steaming hot, gushing red liquid is a bad thing. And they most certainly do have companions, friends, that they prefer to spend their time with. They can smell death, the smell of blood and shit and piss and fear, they know it, just as you and I do.
nameStakeHolder: Internet debate with several Reddit users
nameSource: Reddit - The ethical arguments for veganism are hollow null Reddit Forum

assertion: Humans are accountable for their choice because they can reason and have ethics. Such things is not asked from unaccoutable beings like child, mentally handicaped or animals
explanation: "The thing distinguishing us from other species in this context is that we know that we have ethics. There's no way to know unambiguously if a bear can reason about the justification for killing, so we make the most conservative assumption: that bears (and other animals) do not know ""right"" from ""wrong"", and cannot be held accountable or blamed for their actions. We make the same assumption with children, mentally handicapped people, or even occasionally mentally ill people: if your sense of reason is impaired (either by being undeveloped or through injury), you are not held to the same standards of guilt as a rational adult (e.g. in a legal sense). We're not claiming to be superior or inferior to other animals, just different, adapted to do different things. We're held to a higher standard because we know that our species can (in general) reason we don't know that about other species, so it is safer to"
nameStakeHolder: Internet debate with several Reddit users
nameSource: Reddit - The ethical arguments for veganism are hollow null Reddit Forum

assertion: Eating meat may be ethical but factory farm makes it unethical anyway
explanation: It may not be inherently unethical for humans to eat meat, but the way animals are raised in factory farms is unethical, hence the ethics argument for veganism is still relevant.
nameStakeHolder: Internet debate with several Reddit users
nameSource: Reddit - The ethical arguments for veganism are hollow null Reddit Forum

assertion: Human malnutrition derives from rising livestock eating grain worldwide
explanation: "the sharp rise in the number of the world's livestock, and the connection between their consumption of grain and human malnutrition. After reviewing the figures, I concluded that veganism ""is the only ethical response to what is arguably the world's most urgent social justice issue"""
nameSource: Guardian - I was wrong about veganism. Let them eat meat – but farm it properly null British Newspaper
aim: Ensuring access to food for all humans

assertion: The conversion ratio is better than once thought for meat production compared with plants
explanation: If pigs are fed on residues and waste, and cattle on straw, stovers and grass from fallows and rangelands – food for which humans don't compete – meat becomes a very efficient means of food production. The global average conversion ratio of useful plant food to useful meat is not the 5:1 or 10:1 cited by almost everyone, but less than 2:1
nameSource: Guardian - I was wrong about veganism. Let them eat meat – but farm it properly null British Newspaper
aim: Ensuring access to food for all humans

assertion: Beef production uses a lot of water
explanation: Like many greens I have thoughtlessly repeated the claim that it requires 100,000 litres of water to produce every kilogram of beef
nameSource: Guardian - I was wrong about veganism. Let them eat meat – but farm it properly null British Newspaper

assertion: Beef production uses a lot less water than usually said
explanation: Fairlie shows that this figure is wrong by around three orders of magnitude. It arose from the absurd assumption that every drop of water that falls on a pasture disappears into the animals that graze it, never to re-emerge. A ridiculous amount of fossil water is used to feed cattle on irrigated crops in California, but this is a stark exception.
nameSource: Guardian - I was wrong about veganism. Let them eat meat – but farm it properly null British Newspaper

assertion: Livestock is responsible for 18% of GHG
explanation: UN Food and Agriculture Organisation's famous claim that livestock are responsible for 18% of the world's greenhouse gas emissions, a higher proportion than transport
nameSource: Guardian - I was wrong about veganism. Let them eat meat – but farm it properly null British Newspaper

assertion: UN report on livestock GHG emisions is inaccurate. Livestock account for 10% of GHG
explanation: It attributes all deforestation that culminates in cattle ranching in the Amazon to cattle: in reality it is mostly driven by land speculation and logging. It muddles up one-off emissions from deforestation with ongoing pollution. It makes similar boobs in its nitrous oxide and methane accounts, confusing gross and net production
nameSource: Guardian - I was wrong about veganism. Let them eat meat – but farm it properly null British Newspaper

assertion: Vegan farming kills and exclude animals too
explanation: vegan farming necessitates the large-scale killing or ecological exclusion of animals: in this case pests
nameSource: Guardian - I was wrong about veganism. Let them eat meat – but farm it properly null British Newspaper

assertion: Vegan and vegetarian diet grain does not have a higher carbon footprint than raising livestock
explanation: There’s been a rumour that the grains on which vegan and vegetarian diets are based have a higher footprint than raising livestock, aka the “grain drain”. It’s a myth. While some crops have a shocking eco profile (soy, for example, grown in deforested monocultures), in 2005 one-third of the world’s cereal harvest went to feed livestock.
nameSource: Guardian - Is being vegan the most ethical way to live? null British Newspaper

assertion: Livetsock produces 18% of GHG emissions
explanation: In 2006 the UN’s Food and Agricultural Organisation (FAO) produced a report, Livestock’s Long Shadow, estimating that our meat consumption was responsible for 18% of anthropogenic gas emissions, revising it in 2013 to 14.5%, which is still pretty significant.
nameSource: Guardian - Is being vegan the most ethical way to live? null British Newspaper

assertion: Raising livestock limits desertification
explanation: According to ecologist Allan Savory, livestock is an essential part of bringing nutrients to that topsoil and staving off the desertification of arable land. His theory advocates bunched livestock farming, driving it through pastures to stimulate grazing.
nameSource: Guardian - Is being vegan the most ethical way to live? null British Newspaper

assertion: Most livestock systems are not in desertification prone areas
explanation: The livestock systems that dominate have nothing in common with Savory’s vision.
nameSource: Guardian - Is being vegan the most ethical way to live? null British Newspaper

assertion: Eat less meat and more nuts/legumes reduce the environmental impact
explanation: Science-based organisations insist that we need to reduce our reliance on resource-intensive livestock and invest in variety. We need to grow and eat more nuts and legumes – and research suggests there’s a huge opportunity for the UK to farm more of both. Being a meat reducer is definitely a move in the right direction.
nameProperty: Environmental impact of nuts and legumes
nameSource: Guardian - Is being vegan the most ethical way to live? null British Newspaper

assertion: Vegans for health reasons tend not to stay vegan
explanation: Under an article entitled “Why Jack's Book Matters,” Matt Ball argues that it is “unrealistic” to think many people will give up animal foods just to benefit their long-term health, and that when asked why they quit being vegan, the main reason people give most is because of health. Thus, reasons Ball, the “health argument” is defective, makes people quit being vegan, and “has created much, much more [animal] suffering.”
nameSource: How the ethical argument fails Veganism null Internet article

assertion: People can become Vegan while eating junk food and think the vegan diet is unhealthy
explanation: Too often people switch from the Standard American Diet to a vegan diet with a lot of junk foods in it. They substitute unhealthy alternative products for the unhealthy meat and dairy products, and end up concluding that the vegan diet isn't all that healthy
nameSource: How the ethical argument fails Veganism null Internet article

assertion: Health benefit of veganism are overstated
explanation: "AR dietitian Ginny Messina has written, ""The science of nutrition holds just as many questions as answers and we have no idea what the 'ideal' diet is."" She says elsewhere that ""the health benefits of veganism are overstated."""
nameSource: How the ethical argument fails Veganism null Internet article

assertion: Humane animal food is impossible
explanation: Even the most humane forms of rearing and killing animals for food always violates the animal's most basic interest - to continue living. Modern agriculture often violates other key animal interests as well - for example: to live in natural (or at least, decent) conditions, to make free choices, to be free from fear and pain, to live healthy lives without needing medical intervention, to eat a natural diet, to enjoy the normal social/family/community life of its species

assertion: Plant proteins lower quality can be improved

assertion: Vegetarian diet brings health benefits
explanation: Vegetarian diet reduces the relative risk of diabetes, cancer and coronary mortality by 41%, 10% and 20 % respectivly compared to a conventional omnivorous diet.

assertion: Vegetarian diet brings health benefits
explanation: Vegetarian diet reduces the relative risk of diabetes, cancer and coronary mortality by 41%, 10% and 20 % respectivly compared to a conventional omnivorous diet.

assertion: Vegetarians also appear to have lower low-density lipoprotein cholesterol levels, lower blood pressure, and lower rates of hypertension and type 2 diabetes than nonvegetarians
explanation: Vegetarian diets tend to be lower in saturated fat and cholesterol, and have higher levels of dietary fiber, magnesium and potassium, vitamins C and E, folate, carotenoids, flavonoids, and other phytochemicals. These nutritional differences may explain some of the health advantages of those following a varied, balanced vegetarian diet.

explanation: Vegetarian diets tend to be lower in saturated fat and cholesterol, and have higher levels of dietary fiber, magnesium and potassium, vitamins C and E, folate, carotenoids, flavonoids, and other phytochemicals. These nutritional differences may explain some of the health advantages of those following a varied, balanced vegetarian diet.

assertion: The suffering of plants is an argument to avoid the problem of speciesism, exploitation and violence
explanation: Plant are sensitive but animals have a nervous system which make them suffer
nameSource: VeganFrance.fr - Le cri de la carotte null Vegan Web Directory

assertion: Meat-based diet exterminates more plants than a vegan diet
explanation: Plants are cultivated to feed animals causing plant resources and water shortages, food crisis and conflicts.
nameSource: VeganFrance.fr - Le cri de la carotte null Vegan Web Directory

assertion: Eat less meat and more nuts/legumes reduce the environmental impact
explanation: Science-based organisations insist that we need to reduce our reliance on resource-intensive livestock and invest in variety. We need to grow and eat more nuts and legumes – and research suggests there’s a huge opportunity for the UK to farm more of both. Being a meat reducer is definitely a move in the right direction.
nameSource: Guardian - Is being vegan the most ethical way to live? null British Newspaper

assertion: the livestock sector emerges as one of the top two or three most significant contributors to the most serious environmental problems
explanation: "at every scale from local to global.""[25] The livestock sector is probably the largest source of water pollution (due to animal wastes, fertilizers, and pesticides), contributing to eutrophication, human health problems, and the emergence of antibiotic resistance. It accounts also for over 8% of global human water use."
nameSource: Ethics of eating meat null Wikipedia

assertion: producing animal-based food is typically much less efficient than the harvesting of grains, vegetables, legumes, seeds, and fruits regarding water and energy consumption
explanation: Producing 1 kg of meat requires up to 15,000 liters of water.[35] According to the United States Department of Agriculture (USDA), growing crops for farm animals requires nearly half of the US water supply and 80% of its agricultural land. Animals raised for food in the US consume 90% of the soy crop, 80% of the corn crop, and 70% of its grain
nameProperty: Agricultural land use in the US
nameSource: Ethics of eating meat null Wikipedia

assertion: Animals like oysters can be eaten if they dont feel pain
explanation: Biologically, oysters are not in the plant kingdom, but when it comes to ethical eating, they are almost indistinguishable from plants. Oyster farms account for 95 percent of all oyster consumption and have a minimal negative impact on their ecosystems there are even nonprofit projects devoted to cultivating oysters as a way to improve water quality. Since so many oysters are farmed, there's little danger of overfishing. No forests are cleared for oysters, no fertilizer is needed, and no grain goes to waste to feed them—they have a diet of plankton, which is about as close to the bottom of the food chain as you can get. Oyster cultivation also avoids many of the negative side effects of plant agriculture: There are no bees needed to pollinate oysters, no pesticides required to kill off other insects, and for the most part, oyster farms operate without the collateral damage of accidentally killing other animals during harvesting
nameSource: Ethics of eating meat null Wikipedia

assertion: Green manures and biosolids could cover the global fertility gap if animal/synthetic fertilizers were removed
explanation: By using Veganic farming and technology. eg green manure/mulches, supporting phosphate recycling of human waste. I don’t see how animals would help the problems. Indeed animal agriculture often make that worse. If you look at nitrogen cycles for example, it makes little sense to think of manure as adding to nitrogen sustainability. They just move the nitrogen fixed either by bacteria in the roots of some plants, or fixed by humans in the syntheitic production of fertiliser from one area to another. The same thing could be done just by rotational cropping and green manures
nameSource: Medium.com - I Lost an Argument with a Vegan. Here’s what I Learned null Internet article

assertion: The conversion ratio is better than once thought for meat production compared with plants
explanation: If pigs are fed on residues and waste, and cattle on straw, stovers and grass from fallows and rangelands – food for which humans don't compete – meat becomes a very efficient means of food production. The global average conversion ratio of useful plant food to useful meat is not the 5:1 or 10:1 cited by almost everyone, but less than 2:1
nameProperty: Conversion ratio for livestock fed with residues
nameSource: Guardian - I was wrong about veganism. Let them eat meat – but farm it properly null British Newspaper

assertion: Plant proteins lower quality can be improved
explanation: Plant protein digestibility is improved by cooking
nameSource: Valorial - Argumentaire protéine végétale (citing Young & Pellett 1994, Ruales & Nair 1992, Craig et al. 2009, Le & Sabaté 2014, Morley 1997, Fleischer et al. 2016) null Slideshow
